body: Maybe there's some fun around parsing numbers with a localised decimal point? Try maybe '0.0001'  or just '1'

I once pushed for a proper fix for this in #2227 (which eliminates the need for users to fiddle around with the config files) but it was nuked & locked because I pointed out the logical fallacy behind this broken implementation which assumes "1% your HDD is smaller than the space syncthing needs, regardless of the size of your HDD". (for the record, my particular case is an 8TB, which is nothing surprising these days and %1 corresponds to 80GB, which is way way below the space syncthing actually need).

And mind you, disk sizes are only going to grow. And I'm not even talking about LVM or  btrfs multi-device fs. You can buy 10TB single 3.5" HDDs today on amazon and Samsung is ready to ship its 16TB SSDs. The storage technology develops much faster than my syncthing archive. This is my particular case of course but it's totally irrational to make any assumptions about consumer fs size vs sync data size _by default_.

**File system size, disk size, sync data size and minimum additional free space are orthogonal concepts which happen to have the same units and it makes no sense to measure one in units of the other.**

Syncthing is the only program that I use whose settings will get screwed up when you migrate your data to another disk or expand your FS. The norm is quite simple: let the user set minimum free space _in GBs_, which defaults to a sensible value such as 1GB, and that would be the end of this, and there wouldn't be baffled users trying to make your mistake right by searching google to figure out what the heck is wrong (because surprise surprise, they actually have a lot more space than the data they're syncing) and fiddling around with obscure settings in config files, with one hand on a calculator.

It's easier to go into denial and sweep it under the rug by introducing hacky workarounds and locking to issue and forcefully silence the reporter rather than admitting that you screwed up your design choice and fixing it.

So there's a lot of vitriol here that I'm not going to comment on, I just want to note that

> which defaults to a sensible value such as 1GB

is more or less the reason we don't do this, as defaulting to 1GB would be a bad idea for devices with 1 GB of flash, for example. That is, the default needs to be responsive to the device size, which ends up looking a lot like a percentage.

No, actually I'll comment on this as well...

> It's easier to go into denial and sweep it under the rug by introducing hacky workarounds and locking to issue and forcefully silence the reporter rather than admitting that you screwed up your design choice and fixing it.

The issue you refer to was closed because it was essentially a duplicate of the previous four issues that I linked to when closing it. And no, that amount of denial, sweeping, hacking and silencing sound like a lot of work compared to admitting we're wrong and fixing it. And we do that often enough.

> defaulting to 1GB would be a bad idea for devices with 1 GB of flash, for example.
> 
> the default needs to be responsive to the device size

ok, yes. so why not set the default to 5% of total space in GB / MB / kB? Then the value can be easily edited without calculating it yourself.
Yep I wouldn't be opposed to that. The downside is that it requires some dynamic figuring out the threshold at folder creation time. Pull requests welcome.

> is more or less the reason we don't do this, as defaulting to 1GB would be a bad idea for devices with 1 GB of flash, for example. That is, the default needs to be responsive to the device size, which ends up looking a lot like a percentage.

1GB, 100MB, it doesn't matter. Make the default based on the device size. I'm talking about the way the free space is measure, not its default value.

You don't need to measure the free space in units of file system size (which is broken in various ways as I explained above --and think about it, who else does _that_?  torrent clients? dropbox? bittorrent sync? amule? other p2p programs? I don't know where the idea originated from, but regardless, virtually all p2p file sharing programs measure minimum free space in units of bytes, not filesystem size) in order to make the default something like minimum of, say, 100MB and 5% of total space (without the minimum, there won't be an upper bound and you'd end up requiring 500GBs minimum space on a 10TB HDD).

> And no, that amount of denial, sweeping, hacking and silencing sound like a lot of work compared to admitting we're wrong and fixing it. And we do that often enough.

I do appreciate all the effort that goes into syncthing. That being said, no, not in this case. All you needed to do was to click on the lock issue button (rather than _closing_ the issue, which was quite rude) and [change the type of MinHomeDiskFreePct from int to float64](https://github.com/calmh/syncthing/commit/41c131d840ffcb5eb26f930ce73d7185aa54d963), which is was trivial workaround the issue (again, I'm talking about the way this setting works, not its default value). Doesn't seem to me "a lot of work compared to admitting we're wrong and fixing it". Especially given the fact that you're still in denial about the problem.

Dude, be nice. When people give you good things for free, don't be mean to them. That makes them stop wanting to give out free stuff, and everyone else suffers.

I mean that in all seriousness - developing a OS project like this is a hobby. People keep doing it because it's fun. Having to deal with people who are being rude is not fun, and it takes all the fun out of everything else. Now when you're deciding what to do on your Friday night, you can either go out or deal with mean people on GitHub, and you start to think that going out seems more attractive...

OK, then, I'm sowwy with cherry topped pretty pretty please.
Now can you please try to focus on the _technical_ point that I'm making here rather than the subjective niceness score or pH value.

If you can do that for a moment, you'll see that I'm also writing technical feedback in the hopes of making syncthing better (as opposed to having off-topic and unproductive arguments on github, like this one).

No need to be sarcastic now :)

> change the type of MinHomeDiskFreePct from int to float64, which is was trivial workaround the issue

...

> Pull requests welcome.

> No need to be sarcastic now :)

It wasn't meant to be sarcasm. That's literally how the issue was "solved".

And in case you haven't noticed, that "Pull requests welcome." belongs to a context, which reads:

> ok, yes. so why not set the **default** to 5% of total space in GB / MB / kB? Then the value can be easily edited without calculating it yourself.
> 
> Yep I wouldn't be opposed to that. The downside is that it requires some dynamic figuring out the threshold at folder creation time. Pull requests welcome.

To me it seems he is so far opposed to measuring min free space in bytes and not in fs size in general, for which I'm pretty sure pull requests are _not_ welcome. (Not that I'm not familiar with syncthing internals anyway).

I'm going to lock this issue as well, because you clearly have an axe to grind and I'm tired of it.

Let me restate this though: I think the issue is valid, and I'll welcome a pull request to fix it. @davidak's suggestion to default to some percentage at folder creation time (e.g., one percent as we do now) and then lock that value in as a number of MB or GB and allowing it to be edited as such is perfectly fine. A pull request that implements that _is_ welcome.

issue.body:
I just upgraded syncthing on OS X to 0.14.15 (because I was prompted to)
Now all synchronisation are stopped  stating there would be insufficent free disk space.
As I only need some MB for configuration files beeing synced; i set the limit within the extended (? "Erweiter" in German) syncfolder configuration to 0.0 percent. The sync still is stopped and the error status is "home disk has insufficient free space" remains.
The synced folder is on the main disk containing the /Users folder where users home directories reside ion OS X.
(/home is kind of pseudo filesystem on OS X and reported to be 100% full by "df /home". Unmounting it does not change the picture )

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.14.15, Mac OS X (64 bit)
OS Version: OSX Yosemite 10.10.5
Browser Version: Firefox 44.0.2

issue.body:
### Purpose

This deprecates the current minDiskFreePct setting and introduces minDiskFree. The latter is, in it's serialized form, a string with a unit. We accept percentages ("2.35%") and absolute values ("250 k", "12.5 Gi"). Common suffixes are understood. The config editor lets the user enter the string, and validates it.

We still default to "1 %", but the user can change that to an absolute value at will.

### Testing

Unit tests on the parsing. Manual testing that the checks themselves still work.
